answers.author: Mary McKittrick
answers.text:
The City of Geneva IL provides only meeting stipends (and of course SS/Medicare as required by law).  We do not provide any insurance or other benefits.  Our policy has been to not treat elected officials like employees with benefits.  Elected officials who volunteer their time for public service typically have careers or other means of income and since their service can be short-lived we have decided that resources (that cost the City) should be allocated to public services for our citizens and then for our public servant employees, rather than for Council members.

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
Does the council want more compensation?  Does the council think they need more compensation.  Often time elected officials get other benefits from public service, outside of specific compensation.  Figure out what they want before assuming it is more financial compensation.  Maybe it is more recognition, respect, involvement??

author: Veronica Kloff
text:
The City of Naperville is interested in creative ways to compensate city council. The municipality currently compensates on average approximately $12,879.85 as gross income, and benefits such as life insurance, medicare, social security, IMRF, and health. 
How do other municipalities in our outside of Illinois deal with Council compensation? Does anyone have any examples of packages or options available? 
Any input would be extremely helpful and beneficial! 
Thank you,
Veronica Kloff
kloffv@naperville.il.us
title: Creative Ways to Compensate City Council
